 019: 
 020: # TO-DO: convert DDTW and WDDTW to use slope-based derivatives rather than np.diff
 021: 
 022: # Adapted version of the DTW algorithm taken from https://github.com/hfawaz/aaltd18/tree/master/distances/dtw
 023: #
 024: # @InProceedings{IsmailFawaz2018,
 025: #   Title                    = {Data augmentation using synthetic data for time series classification with deep residual networks},
 026: #   Author                   = {Ismail Fawaz, Hassan and Forestier, Germain and Weber, Jonathan and Idoumghar, Lhassane and Muller, Pierre-Alain},
 027: #   Booktitle                = {International Workshop on Advanced Analytics and Learning on Temporal Data, {ECML} {PKDD}},
 028: #   Year                     = {2018}
 029: # }
 030: #
 031: # Thanks in particular to GitHub @hfawaz!
 032: #
 033: # it takes as argument two time series with shape (l,m) where l is the length
 034: # of the time series and m is the number of dimensions
 035: # for multivariate time series
 036: # even if we have univariate time series, we should have a shape equal to (l,1)
 037: # the w argument corresponds to the length of the warping window in percentage of
 038: # the smallest length of the time series min(x,y) - if negative then no warping window
 039: # this function assumes that x is shorter than y
 040: # def dtw_distance(np.ndarray[double, ndim=2] x, np.ndarray[double, ndim=2] y , double w):
 041: #     # make sure x is shorter than y
 042: #     # if not permute
 043: #     cdef np.ndarray[double, ndim=2] X = x
 044: #     cdef np.ndarray[double, ndim=2] Y = y
 045: #     cdef np.ndarray[double, ndim=2] t
 046: #
 047: #     if len(X)>len(Y):
 048: #         t = X
 049: #         X = Y
 050: #         Y = t
 051: #
 052: #     cdef int r,c, im,jm,lx, jstart, jstop, idx_inf_left, ly, band
 053: #     cdef Py_ssize_t i, j
 054: #     cdef double curr
 055: #
 056: #     lx = len(X)
 057: #     ly = len(Y)
 058: #     r = lx + 1
 059: #     c = ly +1
 060: #
 061: #     if w < 0:
 062: #         band = max_c_int(lx,ly)
 063: #     else:
 064: #         band = int(w*max_c_int(lx,ly))
 065: #     cdef np.ndarray[double, ndim=2] D = np.zeros((r,c), dtype=np.float64)
 066: #
 067: #     D[0,1:] = DBL_MAX
 068: #     D[1:,0] = DBL_MAX
 069: #
 070: #     D[1:,1:] = np.square(X[:,np.newaxis]-Y).sum(axis=2).astype(np.float64) # inspired by https://stackoverflow.com/a/27948463/9234713
 071: #
 072: #
 073: #     for i in range(1,r):
 074: #         jstart = max_c_int(1 , i-band)
 075: #         jstop = min_c_int(c , i+band+1)
 076: #         idx_inf_left = i-band-1
 077: #
 078: #         if idx_inf_left >= 0 :
 079: #             D[i,idx_inf_left] = DBL_MAX
 080: #
 081: #         for j in range(jstart,jstop):
 082: #             im = i-1
 083: #             jm = j-1
 084: #             D[i,j] = D[i,j] + min_c(min_c(D[im,j],D[i,jm]),D[im,jm])
 085: #
 086: #         if jstop < c:
 087: #             D[i][jstop] = DBL_MAX
 088: #
 089: #     return D[lx,ly]
 090: 
 091:
